msg.data:
RDD, Dataset and Dataframe Operations

Welcome to the notebook with the exercises for the fourth session. You’re well on your way to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!

If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise #1 - Using Dataframes

Using the [Titanic dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic), can you calculate the ground truth (number of survivors and deaths) registered on the dataset?
The expected answer would be an object that contains the `survivors` and `deaths` count columns.

For this exercise we’ll need to do several things: 

- Read and load the Titanic dataset from the input bucket at:
  `gs://de-training-input/titanic/train.csv`
- Perform a combination of operations on this dataset such as `grouping`, `aggregation`, `filtering`, etc.

msg.data:
Exercise #1 - Using Dataframes

Using the Titanic dataset, can you calculate the ground truth (number of survivors and deaths) registered on the dataset?
The expected answer would be an object that contains the survivors and deaths count columns.

For this exercise we’ll need to do several things:

  • Read and load the Titanic dataset from the input bucket at:
    gs://de-training-input/titanic/train.csv
  • Perform a combination of operations on this dataset such as grouping, aggregation, filtering, etc.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise #2 - Using Datasets

Using the `Flights dataset`, can you calculate the total registered flights per ORIGIN `and` the number of total destinations for those places?
The expected answer would be a Dataset object that contains the `ORIGIN_COUNTRY_NAME`, `total_flights_from` and `total_flights_to` columns.

For this exercise, we’ll need to do several things: 

- Read and load the Flights dataset from the input bucket at:
    `gs://de-training-input/flight-data/*.csv`
- Perform a combination of operations on this dataset such as `grouping`, `aggregation`, `filtering`, etc.

msg.data:
Exercise #2 - Using Datasets

Using the Flights dataset, can you calculate the total registered flights per ORIGIN and the number of total destinations for those places?
The expected answer would be a Dataset object that contains the ORIGIN_COUNTRY_NAME, total_flights_from and total_flights_to columns.

For this exercise, we’ll need to do several things:

  • Read and load the Flights dataset from the input bucket at:
    gs://de-training-input/flight-data/*.csv
  • Perform a combination of operations on this dataset such as grouping, aggregation, filtering, etc.
